Tomato___Bacterial_spot.name: Bacterial Spot
symptoms: Small, dark brown to black spots on leaves
Leaves may yellow and drop prematurely

organic: Remove and destroy infected plant parts
Apply copper-based fungicides (available at ACE Hardware UAE, Plantopia)
Use neem oil spray as preventive measure
chemical: Apply early morning to avoid leaf burn in UAE heat

prevention: Use disease-free seeds and transplants
Avoid overhead watering (use drip irrigation)
Space plants adequately for UAE's humid conditions
Rotate crops (avoid planting tomatoes in same spot for 2-3 years)
Clean garden tools with 10% bleach solution
Tomato___Bacterial_spot.uae_notes: Common during humid winter months (Nov-Feb). Monitor plants closely during morning dew periods.

Tomato___Early_blight.name: Early Blight
symptoms: Dark brown spots with concentric rings (target-like pattern)

organic: Apply baking soda spray (1 tbsp per liter water)
Use compost tea as foliar spray
Mulch around plants to prevent soil splash

prevention: Stake plants to improve air circulation
Water at soil level, not on leaves
Apply 5-10cm mulch layer
Remove plant debris at end of season
Use resistant varieties when possible
Tomato___Early_blight.uae_notes: Most common tomato disease in UAE home gardens. Worse in warm, humid conditions. Best growing season: October-March.

Tomato___Late_blight.name: Late Blight
symptoms: Large, irregular, water-soaked spots on leaves
White fuzzy growth on leaf undersides (in humid conditions)
Fruit develops firm, dark, greasy spots

organic: IMMEDIATE removal and destruction of infected plants
Do NOT compost infected material - dispose in trash

prevention: Plant resistant varieties
Ensure excellent drainage
Avoid planting near potato crops
Monitor weather - worst in cool, wet conditions
Inspect plants daily during high-risk periods
Tomato___Late_blight.uae_notes: Less common in UAE due to dry climate, but can occur during unusually rainy winters or in overwatered gardens. Act fast if detected.

Tomato___Leaf_Mold.name: Leaf Mold
symptoms: Pale green/yellowish spots on upper leaf surface
Olive-green to brown velvety growth on leaf undersides
prevention: Space plants generously (60cm apart minimum)
Prune lower leaves to improve air flow
Use drip irrigation, avoid wetting leaves
Maintain humidity below 85%
Grow resistant varieties
Tomato___Leaf_Mold.uae_notes: Common in indoor/greenhouse growing which is popular in UAE. Ensure good ventilation in enclosed growing spaces.

Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.name: Septoria Leaf Spot
symptoms: Small circular spots (2-3mm) with dark edges
Spots have tan/gray centers with tiny black dots
Starts on lower leaves after first fruit set

chemical: Begin sprays at first sign of disease

prevention: Rotate crops for 2-3 years
Stake plants to keep off ground
Water at soil level early in day
Remove plant debris thoroughly
Use disease-free seeds
Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.uae_notes: Can spread rapidly in UAE winter humidity. Check plants regularly, especially after rain or morning dew.

Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider.name: Spider Mites
symptoms: Fine stippling/speckling on leaves (tiny yellow dots)

organic: Spray plants forcefully with water to dislodge mites
chemical: Avoid overusing chemicals - mites develop resistance

prevention: Keep plants well-watered (stressed plants attract mites)
Mist plants to increase humidity
Remove heavily infested leaves
Inspect new plants before bringing into garden
Encourage natural predators
Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider.uae_notes: VERY common in UAE due to hot, dry summer conditions. Regular monitoring essential. Consider growing tomatoes only in cooler months (Oct-Mar).

Tomato___Target_Spot.name: Target Spot
symptoms: Brown spots with concentric rings (similar to early blight)
Can affect leaves, stems, and fruit

chemical: Rotate fungicide classes to prevent resistance

prevention: Maintain proper plant spacing
Stake and prune for good air flow
Avoid overhead irrigation
Remove plant debris after harvest
Practice crop rotation
Tomato___Target_Spot.uae_notes: Often confused with early blight. Both require similar treatment. Focus on prevention through good growing practices.

Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.name: Yellow Leaf Curl Virus (TYLCV)
symptoms: Young leaves curl upward and inward

organic: NO CURE - remove and destroy infected plants immediately
DO NOT compost - bag and dispose in trash
Use yellow sticky traps for whiteflies
Apply neem oil to reduce whitefly populations

prevention: Use resistant varieties (look for 'Ty' gene in variety name)
Install fine mesh screens on greenhouse openings
Control weeds that harbor whiteflies
Use reflective mulches to repel whiteflies
Start with healthy transplants from reputable sources
Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.uae_notes: Whiteflies are MAJOR pests in UAE. This virus is significant concern. Use resistant varieties and focus heavily on whitefly prevention. Consider growing during cooler months when whitefly pressure is lower.

Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.name: Tomato Mosaic Virus (ToMV)
symptoms: Light and dark green mottled pattern on leaves
Leaves may be distorted or fern-like

organic: Virus is extremely stable - survives on tools, hands, debris
Disinfect all tools with 10% bleach or milk solution
Wash hands thoroughly after handling infected plants
chemical: No chemical treatment exists for plant viruses
Focus entirely on prevention and vector control

prevention: Use certified virus-free seeds and transplants
Wash hands before and after handling plants
Disinfect tools between plants (milk dip works!)
Do not smoke near plants (tobacco mosaic related)
Remove and destroy infected plants immediately
Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.uae_notes: Less common than TYLCV but very persistent. Once in your garden, difficult to eliminate. Strict hygiene practices essential. Consider starting fresh with new soil if persistent problem.

Tomato___healthy.name: Healthy

organic: Monitor regularly for early signs of problems
chemical: No treatment needed for healthy plants
Consider preventive fungicide if high-risk conditions

prevention: Maintain current good practices
Ensure proper nutrition (especially calcium for blossom end rot prevention)
Keep consistent watering (avoid wet-dry cycles)
Provide adequate support for growing plants
Continue monitoring for pests and diseases
Tomato___healthy.uae_notes: Best growing season in UAE: October to March. Protect from extreme summer heat. Consider shade cloth (30-40%) during hot periods. Use quality potting mix from UAE garden centers like Plantopia, ACE, or Dubai Garden Centre.

sources: UAE Ministry of Climate Change and Environment
